div.p: A Comedie. As it hath beene Presented at the Phoenix in Drury-Lane. The Author IAMES SHIRLEY, Servant to Her Majesty.
Et Spes, & ratio Studiorum, in Caesare tantum.
Printed by B. Alsop. and T. Fawcet. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his Shop neere Furnivals-Inne Gate, in Holborne. 1633.

list.item: PHILENZO Lover of Eugenia, under the Disguise and Name of Rollyardo.
BONAMICO a Mountibanke, or decayed Artist.

div.head: To Master WILLIAM PRINNE, Vtter-Barrester of Lincolnes-Jnne.
div.p:
THe fame of your Candor and Innocent Love to Learning, especially to that Musicall part of humane knowledge Poetry, and in particular to that which concernes the Stage and Scene (your selfe as I heare, having lately written a Tragedie) doth iustly chalenge from me this Dedication. I had an early desire to congratulate your happy Retirement, but no Poeme could tempt mee with so faire a circumstance as this in the Title, wherein I take some delight to thinke (not without imitation of your selfe) who have ingeniously fancied such Elegant and apposite names, for your owne Compositions, as Health's Sicknesse, The Vnlovelinesse of Love-lockes, &c.) how aptly I may present you at this time, with The Bird in a Cage. A Comedy, which wanteth I must confesse, much of that Ornament, which the Stage and Action lent it, for it comprehending also another Play or Interlude, personated by Ladies, I must referre to your imagination, The Musicke, the Songs, the Dancing, and other varieties, which I know would have pleas'd you infinitely in the Presentment. I was the rather inclined to make this Oblation, that Posterity might read you a Patron to the Muses, and one that durst in such a Criticall Age, bind vp the Wounds which Ignorance had printed vpon wit and the Professors: Proceed (Inimitable Mecenas)
and having such convenient leysure, and an Pegasus, I meane your Prose (which scorneth the Roade of Common sence, and despiseth any Stile in his way) travell still in the pursuit of new discoveries, which you may publish if you please, in your next Booke of Digressions. If you doe not happen presently to convert the Organs, you may in time confuse the Steeple, and bring every Parish to one Bell.—

This is all I have to say at this time, and my owne Occasions not permitting my personall attendance, I have intreated a Gentleman to deliver this Testimonie of my Seruice, many faults have escaped the Presse, which your Iudgment will no sooner find, then your Mercie correct, by which you shall teach others a Charity to your owne Volumes, though they be all Errata. If you continue where you are, you will every day inlarge your fame, and beside the engagement of other Poets to Celebrate your Roman Constancie, in particular obliege the Tongue and Penne of your Devout Honourer,—

sp.speaker: Orpiano.
sp.p: HE does not meane this building for a Colledge, I hope?

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: That were an ill Foundation, there are more Scholers then can live one by another already; 'tis pitty we should haue more plenty of learned Beggers.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: 'Tis past all my conjecture, why he built it.

lg.l: Signior Perenotto, Captain oth' Guard
Is of Counsell onely with the Duke in't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Signior Orpiano, and Fulvio.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: My Sparke? Whither in such hast? Let vs change Ayre a litle.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You are travailing to your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Madam Donella is newly return'd to Court.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: With the Princesse?

lg.l: She was but late retyr'd into the Country:
What's the matter?
Your Lordships I hope have heard, the Duke sent
Poste for them, as they say, there is something in't.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Does not your Lordship know?

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your Lordships wisedome and mine is much about a scantling then, yet for ought I heare, there be others of the Court as ignorant as we— your Honors pardon I beseech you, I must in all haste to the Princesses Lodging.

lg.l: Farewell Signior.
Your amorous locke has a hayre out of order.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Vm? what an oversight was this of my Barber, I must returne now and have it corrected, deere Sign.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Here's a Courtier that will not misse a hayre of his Complement, when he is to appeare before his Mistris: every morning does this fellow put himselfe upon the Racke, with putting on's apparell, and manfully indures his Taylor, when he skrewes and wrests his body into the fashion of his doublet— but that the Court cannot subsist without a Foole, I should marvaile what this fellow does to follow it.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: There are more have much about his parcell of Braines, the benefit of youth and good clothes procur'd their places, and ignorance and impudence have since maintayn'd em.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Two great helpes as the world goes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Cleere the presence, the Duke is entring.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: I ever was obedient—

lg.l: 'Tis for thy Honor, which I know,
Is to thy selfe a precious sound— that Building
I late erected, then shall be thy Pallace.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Or my Prison Sir, if I doe rightly understand.

lg.l: That name
Is too unworthy of it, my Eugenia,
Nor will it seeme restraint to my lov'd daughter,
Since free to all delights, thy mind shall be
It's owne Commander, every day shall strive
To bring thee in fresh rarities, Time shall bee.
Delighted with thy pleasures, and stay with thee.
Indeed I shall thinke Time has lost his wings
When I am thus Cag'd up.
Thou shalt give
To him feathers when thou pleasest. Mantua
Shall powre her raptures on thee— why have I
A Crowne, but to command what thou canst wish for,
My deere Eugenia.
A Deere it seemes,
For as you had suspicion of my wildnesse,
You'l measure out my walke.
I am thy Father,
Who by example of the wisest Kings,
But build a place to lay my Treasure in,
Safe from the Robber, where Ile place a Guard—

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Doe you suspect I shall breake Prison?

lg.l: To keepe off violence, and solliciting
Which may disturbe thy pleasures, vntill we
Shall find out one to match thy Birth and Vertues,
My Dukedome is too poore that way, maintaine
Thy Fathers Soule: thou hast no bloud to mixe
With any beneath Prince— forget as I shall
Thy Love was ever falling from thy Greatnesse,
Into the Armes of one carryes but stile of Honour.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Sir, I am your Daughter.

lg.l: Th'ast deserv'd my blessing, and thy obedience
In this, new Crownes thy Father: I see I need not
Vrge what I am to move thee, and lay force,
Thy understanding does appeare convinc'd,
And loving duty teaches thee to more,
Then the Command— Perenotto—
What narrow ground I tread? I know he is
Too passionate to be denyed his will,
And yet to yeeld will make me miserable;
'Tis my misfortune to be borne so great.
Each common man and woman can inioy
The ayre, when the condition of a Princesse
Makes me a Prisoner. But I must obey
In hope it will not last— I have a Soule
Is full of gratefull duty, nor will suffer me
Further dispute your precept: you have power
To steere me as you please.
All the Graces
Speake in my Girle— Each syllable doth carry
A Volume of thy Goodnesse: all my Cares
So well rewarded doe convert to sweetnesse
I thanke thy filiall piety: know my Girle
That place wherein I looke so rich a Iewell,
I doe pronounce againe, shall be thy Paradice:
Thy Paradice my Eugenia, saving that
In this man onely finds no being— other
Delights shall streame themselves into thy Bosome,
And those that passe, shall flow agen t'invite
Thy sence to tasting— Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: Your Graces pleasure?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Admit those Ladyes that attend—

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: The Duke shewes much Indulgence.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Obserue the yssue.

lg.l: Wee will not limit thy companions,
Elect what Mantuan Beautyes thou canst best
Delight in, they shall serue thee: or if some
Of your owne Traine, whom we haue thought most proper
To be your personall Guard, affect you, they Enter Donella Katherina, Mardona & Fidelia.
Attend our pleasures: see, they are ignorant
Yet of our purpose, if to any, thy
Affection be not free, thy Breath discharge them,
And point thy owne Attendants.
I shall be pleas'd with your appointment,
Ladyes, I know you loue me.
Doth your Grace hold suspition, any of vs
Serve you not with our heart?
I doe not doubt,
Or if I did, you now approach a Tryall,
For my sake can you be content to be
All Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Ladyes.
sp.p: Prisoners?

lg.l: Yes, shut up close Prisoners, and be bard
The conuersation, nay the sight of men.
Marry Heaven defend, wherein haue we offended
That we must loose the sweet societie
Of Men.

sp.speaker: Mard.
sp.p: How have we forfeyted our freedome?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No man argue— 'tis our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: 'Las Madam, I am new contracted to a handsome Signior.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: I have but newly entertain'd a Servant, that gave me these Gloves, they smell of him still, a sweet Courtyer.

lg.l: Not one man among so many Ladyes?
Not a Gentleman-Vsher? Nor a Page?
How shall we doe Madam?
I beseech your Grace let me be exempted,
If I haue committed an offence, deserues your Anger,
Let one of your Lords cut off my head rather, Sign. Dondolo.
Shall we expresse,
So cold a duty to her highnesse? Fye Ladyes.
You shall but suffer with me: I pertake
As much Seuerity, as any of you shall.
I will expect your duties Lords in silence,
Orpiano, you shall to Ferrara, with
Our daughters picture, your Commissions sealed—
Now faire Ladyes,
I hope y'are fixd to waite vpon Eugenia.
If your restraint be a Burthen, it shall be
In her power to inlarge you, and elect
New Friends into your places.
'Tis our Duties
To obey your Grace and her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Perenotto— Are all things prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: They are my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: For once then let vs vsher you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Whether doe we goe?

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: Ile tell you.

sp.speaker: Done.
sp.p: Whither?

lg.l: To take Phisicke Madam.
The Duke has prepar'd to stay all loosenesse in your bodies
You must be all fast: stone walles and morter will bind.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Come follow with a Courage.

sp.speaker: Donel.
sp.p: I hope we shall be allowed our little Dogs and Monkeyes.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Sweet Madam.
sp.stage: Exit omn. man. Fulv. Orp. Dond. Grutti.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Madam Katherina, they are gone Signior.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Would I had knowne this afore?

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: The Duke will be censur'd for this Act.

lg.l: 'Tis very strange, good Lady,
I read a forc'd obedience in her Eye,
Which hardly held up Raine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Save you deare Sign. which way went the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Newes, Signior Newes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I beseech you I may pertake.

lg.l: Have you forgot there was suspicion
She affected Signior Philenzo the Cardinals Nephew?

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Alas poore Gentleman, he suffers for't.

lg.l: By this restraint he would make her sure, his jealousie
Is not yet over— Signior Morello, is your locke rectified,
You have mist your Lady but a hayres bredth.
Nay, but my Lords and Gentlemen, where are the
Ladies gone indeed?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: We ha' told you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What, committed to New Prison:

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Very true, Signior.

lg.l: Our dancing dayes are done, shut vp close, not
A man must enter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would I were a Mouse then— why, but is the Duke mad!

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Take heed what you say Signior: though we be no Informers, yet walles have Eares.

lg.l: Eares? Would I had left mine behind me, heere's
Newes indeed!

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: And y'ad come a little sooner, you might ha taken your leave, but 'twas your Barbers fault.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would he had left me ith' suds an houre agoe! What shall we doe Gentlemen, 'tis a hard case, when a man that has an intention to marry and live honest—
How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Any thing, nothing: yet a man, yet no man for I want.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What? Th'art no Capon I hope.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Mony sir, will you spare any from your precious sinnes.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Th'art very free.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yet Sir I am in debt.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: What dost owe?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Nobody harme.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Whence cam'st—

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I dropt from the Moone.

lg.l: So me thinkes, thou talk'st very madly—
Th'ast much humour in thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ha yee any thing to doe that yee account impossible Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Why, wilt thou do't?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: And you'l pay for't. Let mee have mony enough and Ile doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes I will hold.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ile lay with thee, what wilt hold—

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Why Paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Grut. Dond.
sp.p: Paradoxes!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hold you a Paradoxe.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Let's heare some.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: There are no beasts but Cuckolds and Flatterers; no cold weather but i'th Dog-dayes; no Physicke to a whoore, no foole to an Alderman, no Scholler to a Iustice of Peace, nor no Souldier to a Belt and Buffe Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: A smart fellow.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The Duke.

lg.l: So my feares are over, in her restraint I bury all my
Iealousies:— How now? What fellowes this?

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Such an Humorist as I neuer before converst withall: it seemes he makes himselfe free of all places.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What would he have?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Thy pardon mighty man, if it be no Treason to pray for thee, save thee, wilt imploy me? 'Tis Vacation, and I want worke, aske me not what I can doe, let me have money enough, and Ile doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You haue your Sences?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Five, the small Birds dare not peepe for him, I take it: I can see greatnesse big with an Impostume, yet towring in the Ayre like a Fawlcon: I can heare a man sweare I am thy Eternall Slave, and will serve thee: when if opportunity were offer'd, for price of a Plush Cloak, he will be the first shall strip thee to the very Soule: I can taste wine that another man payes for, and rellish any thing that comes of free cost: I can smell a Knave through a Bar'd Gowne, a Politician, through a Surplace; a Foole, through a Scarlet out-side: I can touch a Wench better then a Lute, and tell mony with a Secretary, to shew I ha lost my feeling: tush, all's nothing, I have a humour to doe some thing to be talked on, nothing can come amisse to me, let me have mony enough, and my life to a cheese payring, Ile doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You'l except somewhat.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Not to doe o're the Seven Wonders of the World, and demolish 'em when I ha done, let me have money enough, what starre so high, but I will measure by this Iacobs staffe: Divine mony, the Soule of all things Sublunary, what Lawyers tongue will not be tipt with silver, and will not mony with a Iudge make it a plaine Case, does not gowty Greatnesse find ease with Aurum palpabile, and he's a sleight Physitian cannot give a Golden Glister at a dead lift:— Mony, I adore thee, it comes neere the nature of a Spirit, and is so suttle it can creepe in at a Cranny, bee present at the most inward Councels, and betray em: Mony, it opens lockes, drawes Curtaines, buyes wit, sels Honesty, keepes Courts, sights Quarrels, pulls downe Churches, and builds Almeshouses.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A wilde fellow.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Will your Grace have him punisht for this insolence?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, his humor is good mirth to vs; whence art?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I am of no Country.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I was borne vpon the Sea.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: In a Tempest I was told—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A blustering fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thy Name.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Rolliardo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And how long hast thou beene mad thus?

lg.l: Your Highnesse may be merry-and if you have no
Employment for me, I am gone.
Stay we command you, and bethinke agen,
What to except in your bold vndertaking.
I except nothing, nothing Duke, it were no glory
Not to be generall, active in all, let me have Mony
Enough and Ile doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Will your Grace set him aworke?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Name the Action.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What say you to a Lady?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I will fall vpon her, as Iupiter on Danae, let me have a shower of Gold, Acrisius brazen Tower shall melt agen, were there an Army about it, I would compasse her in a Moneth or dye for't.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ha?— A Lady without guard would try your wit, and mony to get her Love.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: A toy, a toy.

lg.l: Through a Credulity, you may too much
Traduce the Sexe, and merit such a Iustice
No Mony will buy off:— admit some Branches
Grow not so straight and beautifull, as Nature
Intended them, will you disgrace the stemme
Or for some womans Levity, accuse
That fayre Creation? Mony buy their Love
Promise a Salary of that sacred flame
Themselves cannot direct, as guided by
Divine intelligence.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
Your Highnesse Pardon; if you prohibite I must not undertake, but let me have freedome, and Mony enough (for that's the Circle I walke in) and if I doe not conjure up a spirit hot enough to inflame a frozen Lucrece bosome: make Mummy of my flesh, and sell me to the Apothecaries: try me with some Master peece; A womans Love is as easie as to eate dinner without saying Grace, getting of Children, or going to bed drunke: Let me have
Money enough, and taxe me to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Fulv. Orp.
sp.p: He's constant.

lg.l: Admit there be a Lady, whom a Prince
Might Court for her Affection; Of a Beauty,
Great as her Vertue, adde unto them Birth,
Equall to both, and all three but in her
Not to be match'd— Suppose this Myracle
(Too precious for mans Eye) were shut vp, where
A Guard more watch ull then the Dragons; did
Forbid accesse to mankind:— Men pick'd out
Betweene whose Soules and Mony were Antipathy
Beyond that which we know; and you assoone
Might bribe to be a Saint:— what would you doe
With your enough of mony, were your life
Ingag'd to winne her Love?
The sky may fall, and Aldermen cry Larkes
About the City.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The fellow's impudent: Sirrah, thou hast landed thy selfe upon a Rocke, you shall have sence of what you would contemne, a Life: put on a most fortified resolution, you shall need it; we haue a daughter thus lock'd up—

sp.speaker: Fulv,
sp.p: What does the Duke meane?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A Virgin.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: He is in Passion.

lg.l: Shalt not ingage thee on a worke so much
Impossible as procurement of her Love,
Make it appeare with all the Art thou canst
Get but accesse to her; a Moneth we limit
But take heed Boaster, if you faile; your Life
Shall onely satisfie our charge, and teach
All other Mountibanks to be at distance,
With such bold undertakings: you shall expect
A severe Iustice:
By this, I shall try the Fidelity of those are trusted.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: 'Tis a match, I shall have mony enough?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall. What d'yee call enough, yet it shall be under 20. thousand Crownes: I will not leave the Pawne here, for twice so much.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I will not be particular and agree oth' Summe, you looke I should dye if I performe not, and Ile looke to bee merry and want nothing while I live, Ile not take the Advantage on you, because I hope to receive credit by it: if I use now and then a round summe set me up oth' Ticket for't, but who shall passe his word if I doe this feate, you'l let me keepe my head a my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Our royall word secure thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: 'Tis enough.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: What security can your Grace expect for his forthcomming, if he fayle.

lg.l: We ha studyed that,
'Tis but the losse of some superfluous Crownes,
Let the end carry what successe Fate please,
All the expence will not be lost, to try
The faith of those we shall imploy in this;
Our Citie's strong, the River that invirons
On three parts, shall be carefully attended,
A wall makes safe the fourth, which shall be guarded
Our Vigils shall be so exact, he shall
Deserve his liberty, if he escape vs,
We are constant Sir.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Would he might pay for his curiositie.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ile waite upon your Highnesse for some earnest: I have a Moneth good, let me have faire play and my bargaine Mony enough, if I doe come short, let my head be too heavie for my shoulders; if I doe more then is expected, you'l beleeve it possible hereafter: when a man has money enough he may doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Maintaine your humour still— attend vs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Here's a mad fellow, does he meane to get into the Ladyes?

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: It seemes so.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Or I wud not be in his taking when the Moon changes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Our best course then is to observe and humor him, he may have a tricke more then we know; he seemes to be a good Fellow, let's be drunke together, and get him to confesse it— ha?

sp.speaker: Don. Grut.
sp.p: A match.

lg.l: Like errand Knights our valiant wits must wrastle
To free our Ladyes from the inchanted Castle.

div.head: Scaena. I.

lg.l: D'Yee thinke this Hayre
And habit will sufficiently disguise you,
From your inquiring Creditors?
No question,
Have you disperst my Billes about the City,
Does every publike place carry the scrole,
As I commanded?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have beene carefull.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: What doe they say abroad, doe they not wonder?

lg.l: They are strucken dumbe at reading, he that has
The use of tongue, employes it to expresse
His admiration of your Art, your deepe,
Invisible Art.
There's hope then we shall prosper,
In this beleeving Age, Jtaly is full
Of Iugling Mountibanks, that shew trickes with oyles,
And powders, here an Emperick dares boast
Himselfe a Paracelsian, and dawbe
Each Post with printed follyes, when he went
A'th ticket with some Midwife, or old woman
For his whole stocke of Physicke, here a fellow
Onely has skill to make a handsome perewig,
Or to sowe teeth i'th gummes of some state Madam,
Which she coughes out agen, when so much phlegme
As would not strangle a poore flea, provokes her,
Proclaimes himselfe a rectifier of Nature,
And is beleev'd so, getteth more by keeping
Mouthes in their quarterly reparations,
Then knowing men for all their Art, and paines
I'th cure of the whole body— shall we doubt
To be made rich, rich Carlo, by our Art
Whereof I am the first and bold Professor
In Jtaly, we shall grow fat and purchase,
Dost not thinke so?
To goe invisible
Who will not learne at any rate.
True Carlo.
There may be in the throng of our admirers,
Some will presume't above the power of Art
To make men walke and talke invisible.
But we can cleere the mistery, and make
Mantua in the proofe acknowledge it
A matter feasible— here's some Customer Enter Rolliardo.
Ha? 'Tis the Humorist, the Vndertaker,
The Bird I spread my Art for, he has mony
Enough, and's apt to prove a fortune to me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: So the Covenants are seal'd, I am like a famous Cathedrall with two ring of Bells, a sweet Chime a both sides, now 'tis noys'd I ha mony enough, how many Gallants of all sorts and Sexes court me, here's a Gentleman ready to run himselfe in the Kennell, for hast to give me the Wall, this Cavalier will kisse my hand, while th'other Signior crinckels ith' hammes, as hee were studying new Postures against his turne comes to salute me. As I walke, euery Window is glaz'd with eyes, as some tryumph were in the street; this Madova invites me to a Banquet for my discourse, t'other Bona roba sends me a Sparke, a third a Ruby, a fourth an Emerald, and all but in hope to put their Iewels to vsury, that they may returne agen with precious Interest— Thus farre it goes well, very well, what's next-

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Save you Signior.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: One appointed by fate to doe you service Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
But I gave fate no Commission to take you up for
me, I ha more followers then the Duke already, prethee have me commended to the Lady Destinyes, and tell 'em I am provided.

lg.l: Mistake me not, he speakes to you, has power
To make you happy.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Prethee make thy selfe happy with a warme suite first, thy house is but poorely thatched, and thou beest so good at making happy, why hast no better clothes.

lg.l: 'Tis no felicity, or admit: the Sunne
Dispenceth a rich warmth about the World
Yet hath no heate it selfe.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Philosophie.

lg.l: To omit circumstance, I know what you
Haue vndertaken to the generall
Amazement: vpon penalty of death,
You must procure accesse to the faire Princesse,
'Tis in my Art to helpe— to perfect what
The Duke holds so imposible.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How canst thou assist mee.

lg.l: Although my outside promise not, my braine
Is better furnished, I ha gain'd by study
A secret, will aduance the worke you labour with,
Ile teach you Sir to goe invisible—

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How? t'hast no clouen foote, I sent brimstone, and thou beest a Diuell tell me.

lg.l: I trifle not, I am a man, whose fame
Shall out-liue time, in teaching you this Mistery
For which I must expect reward— you are,
(Lowd noise proclaimes it) able, & can pay me
Out of the Dukes Exchequer, being your selfe
His walking treasury.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You'l teach me to goe invisible you say.

lg.l: I can, and with your safety, for I deale not
With magick, to betray you to a Faith
Black and Satannicall, I abhorre the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Very like so.

lg.l: Which some haue coniured into a Ring,
To effect the wonder, I admit of no
Suffumigation, incense offer'd to
Infernall Spirits, but by Art, whose Rules
Are lawfull and Demonstrative—

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You thinke I admire you all this while— Harke, when did you eate? or doe you hope agen, that you are put to this pitifull and desperate exigent. I see you my would be Invisible, fine Knave.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: D'ee mocke me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ile tell you a better project, wherein no Courtier has prefool'd you. Sticke your skin with feathers, and draw the rabble of the City for pence a peece to see a monstrous Bird brought from Peru, Baboones have past for men already, beene taken for Vsurers, i'their furr'd Gownes and Night-caps, keepe a foole in pay, to tell the multitude of a Gentle fayth, that you were caught in a Wildernesse, and thou mayst be taken for some farre Country Howlet.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Doe you despise my Art?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Art? but such another word, and I shall marre the whole expectation of your invisible traffique, in, to your nest; and leave me, distinguish men before you practise on 'em, 'tis wholsome caution.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I leave you to the misery of your unbeleefe, when you heare of me hereafter, you will curse your fortune to have thus neglected me, fare you well, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Perenotto, with 3. or 4. of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: This is Perenotto Captaine of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not yet attempted you?
We have not seene him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He's here.
Is that he that has gold enough? would I had some of his yellow hammers.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: D'ee heare, you are one of the List.
A poore Halbert man Sir.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Poore? hold thee, there's gold for thee:— thou woo't be honest now?
O yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Not a peny, and thou hadst not beene a foole, thou wouldst ha bin a Knave, & so thou might'st have got by me, yet by those scuruy legs there's some hope thou't be converted at all adventures take it.
I will be what you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Tell me what condition is that Sign. of? is he rich?
He loves money.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Come? Shalt be my Pensioner— here's more gold for

D'yee make question of that Sir? he bought his Office, & therefore may sell his Conscience, he has sold 200. on's twice over, he was brought up at Court, and knowes what belongs to his place, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Good.
Am I not a Knave now Sir?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I like thee.
To your cost:— I hope you wo'not tell him what I say: but if you doe, and he chance to turne me out of my office, your gold is restorative.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To your stations, and be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Noble Sir, you are the onely man I have Ambition to honour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I should be proud to merit such a Phrase.

lg.l: 'Tis in your power to oblige my Soule— w'are private,
I am jealous of the Wind lest it convey
Our noyse too farre: This Morne I had some traffique
With a Ieweller, and if my Iudgment erre not,
H'as richly furnish'd me.
What sayes your Lordship to this Diamond?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis a glorious one.

lg.l: Does it not sparkle most divinely Signior,
A rowe of these stucke in a Ladies Forehead,
Would make a Persian stagger in his Faith,
And give more Adoration to this Light
Then to the Sun beame: I ha fellowes to 'em
A Nest of bright ones.
This Boxe is studded like a frosty Night with stars
You have out bid their Value, make me a gainer
In changing them for your commends.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I'm serious.

lg.l: I never shall deserve this Bounty, if
You'd point me out some service to begin my gratitude—
You have a Noble Soule
Ile teach you how to merit more.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: I am Covetous of such a knowledge.

lg.l: Make but my path a smooth one to the Princesse,
I am briefe, you know my undertaking.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So I should be a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: It comes not neere the question of a life: do't Ile enable you, to buy another Dukedome, State, and Title.

lg.l: Although 'twere necessary in the Affayres
Of such high consequence to deliberate,
Yet for this once, Ile be as briefe as you,
I wo'not doe't.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: No indeed Signior, you shall pardon me
At this time, and Ile keepe your Iewels too
For they are guifts: hereafter you will know me
So fare you well Sir.
Was I not told this Officer was corrupt?
I want Faith to beleeve the Myracle.
Sure he does but iest with me, ha?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The Guard will accept no money.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What an ago do wee liue in, when officers will take no bribes.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Not the Golden one.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Here's Rolliardo.

sp.speaker: Roll
sp.p: I'me quite lost.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: 'Tis he.

lg.l: Yet he keepes my jewels, there may be some hope
Ile to him agen, 'tis but his modesty
At first not to see me easie, he must be courted
Statesmen like Virgins first, should giue denyall,
Experience and opportunity make the tryall.
Saue you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And you goe thereto: saue your selfe, you are in a worse pickle then wee are.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: And how i'st wee Signiour?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Doe you thriue in your hopes?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I doe not dispaire Gentlemen, you see I doe not weare my hat in my eyes, crucifie my armes, or intreate your Lordships braine to melt in a Petition for me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
I did but iest, I know you haue a way to the
wood in your Pericranium, what is't wee are honest simple minded Lords.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Nay nay, impart.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wee tell no tales.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Woo'd wee were whipt and wee doe.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Why shall I tell you— you are three.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Very secret—

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Coxecombs.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: A miserable leash of Court Mimicks.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mimicks? what's that.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You perfumd Goates.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Oh is that it, I neuer heard what a Mimick was before.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Dee thinke I am so wretched in a point that concernes my life and honour, to trust my wayes and purposes to you that haue no soules.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No soules.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Peace how comes he to know that?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Why hast thou none?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: 'Twas more then euer I could see in my selfe yet.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Things that haue forfeited their Creation, and had not your Tailors tooke compassion on you, you had died to all mens thoughts, who long since wod ha forgotten that euer there were such thinges in Nature.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Shall wee suffer this?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes, and make legs, in token of your thankefullnesse, if I were at leisure, I would make you shew trickes now.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Doe I looke like a Johnanapes?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: But I wonot.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: It were not your best course.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Alas Sir I should but shame my selfe, and be laughed at afore all this Company.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
When you see mee next avoide mee, as you would doe your poore kindred when they come to Court.
Get you home, say your Prayers, and wonder that you come off without beating, for 'tis one of my Myracles.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Had wee not better a gone to Tauerne, as I plotted at first, he could not ha beene more valiant in his drinke.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Im'e glad hees gone.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I know not what to make on him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Make on him quotha, he made little reckning of vs, but and he had not gone as he did, I should ha made

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Vrine in my breeches— he sqeezed me, I thinke I was ready to melt'o, both sides.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: But harke you Signior, wee forget the Ladies still

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Well remembred.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Lets consult to purpose about that— shall wee?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No, euery one thinke what he can by himselfe, my thoughts shall be private, and not free at this time; euery one scratch his owne head.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And he that gets the first hint, communicate—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Let me see— umh.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What if I did— nothing, my braines are dull.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Ten to one, but if I did— let it alone, a pox on't, I were best drinke some Sacke, they say it helpes inuention.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: O rare.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Rub rub, out with it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No, 'tis gone backe agen, I drunke buttered Sacke this Morning and it slipt backe when 'twas almost at my tongues end— but it was a delicate proiect, whatsoeuer it was.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Recouer it with thy finger.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Follow it Morello.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now, now, now, let me alone— make no noise, 'tis comming agen, I ha't, I ha't—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hold it fast now.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Loose it not, thou art great with wit, let vs deliuer thee, what, ist?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Some wiser then some.
sp.stage: They follow him vp and downe for discouery.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wilt not tell vs?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Didst not promise.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No hast— as occasion serves— it cost more then so yet you may know't.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Hereafter, but not now— away, doe not tempt me I will eate the sweat of my owne braine, O rare! neuer was such a straine of wit inuented.— dee heare, Gentlemen; if you will command me any service to the Ladies, I doe purpose to visite em— with quirke— hey.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Marry doe I.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay Morelle.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, as I told you, if you haue any thing to the Ladies, before I goe I am the messenger,— there is a crotchet and so forth— a carwhichet is found out- your eares— I will doe such a stratagem as neuer the like was heard of in the world.— Oh rare.—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hees mad.

lg.l: So am I, that he is so reservd
What shall's doe.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Saue you Signiors, pray where abouts is the signe of the invisible man.

sp.speaker: D. G.
sp.p: The invisible man.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Cry yee mercy now I see it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: See't he does more then wee can, the Gentleman's mistaken, heeres no such signe, yet hee went in there.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Hee has better eyes then wee to distinguish it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This, It his is it.

sp.speaker: Don
sp.p: What is it pray?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Whats that to you?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: In courtesie wee aske:

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Then by the signe this is the house, whether I am going to enquire for a Gentleman that teaches men to walke invisible.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: That wo'd be seene, this is newes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Newes, either you haue slept long, or you are Gentlemen of very small intelligence, examine the next paper you see aduanced, and informe your selues, farewell Gallants.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hee's entred there to.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Teach men to walke invisible, a very fine trade.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Would 'twere true, wee should desire no other device to get into the Ladies.

div.stage: Enter Bonamico and Seruant in other disguises.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible— see, see, more Gentlemen, prethee lets to him, this will bee a tricke worth our learning.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Stay, wee are not acquainted, lets knocke first.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your pleasures Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pray Sir, what signes is this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The invisible man Sir.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Man, I see no man.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Heres nothing but a cloude.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Right Sir, and hee's behinde it, the mans invisible.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pretty faith, It may bee the man i'the Moone for ought wee know.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Would yee any thing with my Master.

sp.speaker: Gurt.
sp.p: He does teach to walke invisible they say.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He is the onely Professor of the miraculous invisible Art.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: May wee change a little discourse with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There are some Gentlemen with him— but I'le tell him, I am preuented, hee's comming forth himselfe.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Signior Altomaro I take it.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis my name Sir, a poore Artist, not warme in these parts of Italy.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And you were not too busie Sir—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Please you walke in, I am now alone, your persons will grace my poore habitation.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wee saw 4. or 5. enter but now.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I ha dispatch 'em they are fresh departed.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Which way.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Here's not a man, are they not suncke, came they out heere?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Vpon my credit Sir no other way.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Then they went invisible.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Right Sir, they came hither to that purpose, their designes required hast.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: This man can doo't I see already.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir if you can assure vs this invisible walking, for wee are not so ignorant as wee seeme, wee ha seene the Play of the Inuisible Knight, and—

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: That of the Ring too, ha ye not.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p:
The one was Magick, and t'other an imposture, what I doe is by Art faire and naturall, are you in debt and feare arresting, you shall saue your money in protections, come vp to the face of a Sergiant, nay walke by a Shole of these mankind horse-leaches, and be mace proofe. If you haue a mind to raile at 'em, or kick some a their loose flesh out, they shannot say blacks your eye, nor with all their linces eyes discouer you: would you see when the Mercers abroad, how his man playes the Merchant at home with his Mistris silkeworme, and deales vnderhand for commodity— would your selfe talke with a Lady in secret, sit downe, play with her, rauish a Diamond from her finger, and bind her soft wrist with a bracelet, kisse her abroad, at home, before her seruants, in the presence
of her jealous husband, nay trusse her vp, when the tame Lord is a bed with her, and to his eyes be vndiscovered as the winde Signior— doe you suspect your Mistris playes double? would you heare how she entertaines the t'others loue, and know what she does i'the closet with the smooth Page— would you be present at secret Counsels, betray letters, see how such a Lord paints his thighes, this perfume his breath, t'other marshall his fine French teeth, see this Statesmans eyes put out with a bribe, how that officer cozens the Duke, and his Secretary abuses 'em both, this Lawyer takes fees a both sides; while the Iudge examines the fertility, and price of the Mannor, before the witnesses and then decrees who shall haue the Land? would you see iustice employ her scales to weigh light Gold, that comes in for fees or corruption, and flourish with her sword like a Fencer to make more roome for causes 'ithe Court.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: All this and more may be done, if we can but goe invisible, but how can you assure vs of that. I would faine see any man goe invisible once.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: See him Sir?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Video pro intelligo I meane Sir.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Nay Sir you need not distinguish, for it is possible to see a man invisible obserue me, you see mee now perfectly, in euery part, if I should walke before you without a body.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: My head onely visible and hanging in the Ayre like a Comet.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: That were a strange sight?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Sometimes nothing shalbe seene but my arme, another while one of my legs, hopping without a body.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: This is admirable.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: When I please I will haue nothing conspicuous, but my hand, nay, perhaps my little finger.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Doe not you conjure then?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Come you will cast a mist before our eyes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis a Mistery indeed but a safe one Signiors.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
Why looke you Sir, if you will be pleased that
wee may see you first walke invisible, wee shall not onely credit your Art, but at any rate be ambitious to bee your Disciples.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, you speake but Iustice, you shall haue experiment. I wilbe invisible first, but as to other in this kinde, I will not demonstrate without halfe in hand, let me haue 50. Crownes apeece, Ile point you a day when I will be invisible.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Can you not doe it presently.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I can be invisible in a twinckling, but what assurance can you haue, that I am here at the same instant, when you see no part of mee, I may deceiue you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He sayes true.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I doe purpose therefore to giue you reality and proofe, for I will walke invisible, all but— my hand.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your hand?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Onely my hand, you shall touch it, see euery line in't, and the rest of my body be to you invisible, this will require a little time for preparation, and when with the consent of your eyes and vnderstandings, I keepe my promise in this point, you will thinke your monies well expended to be taught the Mistery.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: This is very faire.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The crowne shall be ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Expect'em within this houre.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: At your owne pleasures, ha Rolliardo? I must not be seene Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Farewell incomparable Signior— what lucke had wee to light vpon this Artist, he shanot publish it, wee'l buy the whole secret at any value, and then get him remoue into some other Province, who's this.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
Am not I mad, sure I am, though I doe not know it, and all the World is but a Bedlam, a house of correction to whip vs into our sences, I ha knowne the time when jewels and Gold had some vertue in'em, the generation of men now are not subject to corruption; Democritus the
Worlds refin'd.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: 'Tis Rolliardo, he lookes Melancholy, lets haue a fling at him, giue you joy of the great Lady Sir, which is the next way to the Moone pray?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Bolt vpright Muskat, and if you make hast you may be one of her Calues, next time she appeares, you shall see her becken to you, with a paire of hornes, iust a'the size of those are preparing for your forehead, my precious animall.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the fellowes mad.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Can you tell Sir, what became of all the Swallowes, Cuckoes, and small birds, wee had here last Summer?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Marry Sir they went to Sea, to aide the Cranes, and there haue bin mustering euer since, but for want of a Woodcocke they ha left behind 'em, they dare not venture vpon the Pigmies, you may doe well to ouertake the Buzzard and releeue the Army Sir.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I shall be grinnde to death as I walke the streetes, 'tis no policy to be dull and modest— but let me see, which way to compasse my worke, and put my selfe out of the common laughter the very children will ieere mee shortly I thinke, and point me out with stones, the precious vndertaker. I might haue had more wit then to run my selfe into this calamitie whom haue wee next.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, Embassador, Fulvio, Dondolo, Grutti attendants, Courtiers.
sp.p: The Duke? what stranger's that? I must not seeme deiected.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Is this he your Highnesse discoursed of?

lg.l: This is the peece made vp of all performance
The man of any thing without exception,
Giue him but Gold, Kings daughters and their heires
Though lockt in towers of Brasse, are not safe from him.
Nay though I play the chimist with my trust
And from a Million of sure confidences
I draw the spirit of honesty into a few,
He can corrupt 'em.
You are my Prince great Sir, and you haue spoke
Not much vnlike a braue one.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Heele jeere the Duke too

lg.l: If my head
Come to be paid to you, before Sunne-set
That day when it is forfeite, I ha cleerd with you,
And shall depart out of your Royall debt
There's all you can demand, a good sharpe sword
Will make an euen reckning.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: He seemes confident.

sp.speaker: Court. 1.
sp.p: With your Graces leaue, let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Now a fierce dog.
What came into thy mind, thou daring madman, foole is a word of favour to thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: So Sir.
To vndertake such an impossible taske.

lg.l: Mushroumpe— Ile cast away a few words on thee
Had I another life, I'de vndertake yet
Though I below in all opinion,
To venture it, with the riches I haue spread
To corrupt others, to make thee my parasite,
I would engage my life to weare no steps
To thy white daughter, thou and thy graue Matron
Most humbly should present her, when I was pleased too
For feare I should refuse the sport you brought mee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I neuer knew man beare his scorne so high, too him some other.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Not I Sir, you shall excuse me, 'twas the last thing I did.

lg.l: In the position generall, 'Ile not touch him
For mony may be said to purchase all things
But to aspire to my good Soueraignes daughter
Of blessed memory.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Shee's not dead I hope.

lg.l: There Gold and trash was impudently inferr'd,
And 'twas a taske too insolent, in that point
You'd willingly give a pound of your proud flesh,
To be releast.
I heard a pound of flesh, a Iewes demand once
Twas gravely now remembred of your Lordship— releast?
Fortune, and courtesie of opinion
Gives many men Nobility of Birth,
That never durst doe nobly, nor attempt
Any designe, but fell below their Honors.
Cas'd up in Chambers, scarcely ayre themselves
But at a Horse-race, or i'th Parke with Puppets,
That for which I'm your laughter, I speake to
You flattering tribe of Courtiers, to you Glowormes
Is my chiefe glory, that perhaps being sprung
From humble Parentage, dare yet attempt
A deed so farre above me, that sets all
Your Wisedomes in Combustion, you may thinke
I've made a sorry bargaine for my life,
Let Scorners know in ayming at her onely
My memory after death, receives more honour
Then all your marble Pinnacles can raise you,
Or alablaster figures, whiter farre
Then ere your soules were, and that houre I dye
If you dare looke vpon me, without fainting
(Which I much feare) you shall see death so scorn'd,
I meane for any terrour, you shall thinke him
My slave to take my upper Garment off.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I told your Hignesse— How you shud find him.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: A brave Resolution.

lg.l: Be this the Prologue to the mirth, my Lord
Attends to entertaine you; set on, we'll leave him. Ha, ha, ha.
Sir, I observ'd you Noble, and not apt
To throw derision on me with the rest,
Which does encourage me, to aske you a question.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Name it Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Pray what strange'r's that walk'd with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: 'Tis an Embassador from Florence Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: An Embassador, his designe I pray?

lg.l: To treate of Marriage betwixt our Princesse
And the great Dukes sonne, desired much by our'Master
Who has some hope, t' wilbe effected too.
Has brought rich presents to her.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: You haue it freely.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Y'aue honored me, married to Tuscany? so, if my ambition had beene fortunate, I might haue beene his taster, but my starres want influence, they are too dull, and weary of my fate, Rolliardo then must forfeit, why that's the worst on't, I will make a glorious blaze in death, and while I liue, make the Dukes treasure pay for't, nor shall he accuse me, I exhaust him poorely, i'le study out some noble way to build me a remembrance. ha.— a Church or Colledge? Tedious, my glasse has but few sandes, I must doe some thing I may liue to finish: I ha't, I will send to all the prisons ith Citty, and pay the poore mens debts for 'em: the world wants such a President: I ha mony enough since I faile in my other ends, I will doe some good deedes before I dye, so shall I be more sure of Prayers, then if I built a Church, for they are not certaine to continue their foundation, fate I despise thee, I sinke vnder no cheape and common action, but sell my life too Fame, in catching my death by so braue an aspiring.

lg.l: If I obtaine a Monument, be this all
Write on my graue. This man climbe'd high to fall.

div.head: Scaena I.

sp.p: Come Gentlemen, wee must watch still, that none run away with the Princesse.
He must haue an excellent stomacke, that can breake these stone walles to come to her.
Beside this moueable wall of flesh which we carry.
One makes toward vs,— 'tis a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: So, now am I as valiant as Hercules, when he turned spnister, greate Iupiter, the patron of scapes, assist my petticote, and at my returne, I will sacrifice my linnen-breeches to thee,— here be the men, the men of mettle, now Venus I beseech thee, and they bee men they will let a Lady enter without many questions.
Saue you sweet Lady, your affaires this way?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I goe but in to the Princesse.
From whom?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: From the Dukes Grace.
What may be your Ladiships name?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I neuer thought to giue my selfe a name— my name is Madam— um. My name is something an odde name, but— I doe not stand vpon't— my name's Thorne.
Indeed Madam Thorne, if his Grace haue sent you to such a purpose, you must shew something for our discharge.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Why hearke you it was but forgotten, of the Duke to send his signet— but I ha brought some of his Highnesse deputies wo'mee, I hope that will satisfie.
sp.stage: As he takes out mony discouers Breeches.

sp.p: By this gold, breeches
No, they are but silke— here will be sport, I haue a hint already.
Say you so? 'Tis very well— but Madam, we are many, and we would be loth to venture— deale ingeniously sweet Lady, have you no more gold in your breeches?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not a doyt, as I am vertuous and sinfull.
Passe— but d'ee heare— and you shud not be secret now.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman.
A Gentleman? do'st heare him? ile put him to't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have left some Crownes with your fellow.
Tush, that wo'not satisfie me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed, I ha no more mony.
You have commodity, hang this transitory gold— give me— what's this?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nothing but a wart a'my little finger.
A wart, let me see't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis a Diamond, 'twas my Mothers Legacy— or else
Is it your will I should have it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It was my Mothers will I should weare it, her Ghost will haunt me, and I should give it away.
You know the way backe Lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You will give me my gold agen.
Not a doyt, as I am vertuous and sinfull, stand with him for a toy, and know y'ave no warrant from the Duke, 'tis in our power.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: D'ee heare Sir, and it were a Diamond of gold you shud have it.
Lady, I kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Y'ave kiss'd the Ring of a my finger Ime sure.
Vse your fortune, passe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If I get to the Ladies, some body shall pay for this, that's my comfort.
Can you wrastle Madam.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ah— wrastle Sir, Ladies doe not use to wrastle.
They are throwne downe with their good wills then, come you and I will have a bout, I must hug your little body.
Humor him, and y'are past danger.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Wod you ha me teare my clothes?
Ile perswade him.

To tell you true Madam, this fellow is an abhominable
Lecher, there is no scaping him without a fall, a very Satyre, he leapes all comes neare him, if your Ladiships modesty can dispence with a private favour— you understand; for our parts, we are satisfied otherwise, and our lips are sow'd up, take him a 'toside, and see how you can mollifie him, hee's a Cocke a the Game, and will tread you and you were ten Thornes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mollifie him, doth he use Ladies so, he will molifie me.

And you were his sister, all's one to him, the Divell is not more hot and Robustious, where he finds opposition to the sport; therefore the Duke made choyce of him, as suspecting some Lord might come disguis'd a this fashion, to prevent dishonour to the Princesse and Ladies— use your owne discretion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What will become of me, if he be such a Wencher he'll ravish me, and discover all, what a Rascall was I to venture thus, ile giue thee my Fan to perswade him— helpe, helpe.

lg.l: Nay then. He throwes him downe, and discovers his Breeches.
Why how now? Breeches?

sp.p: This is a man.
Sure 'tis a woman.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To tell you true Gentlemen, I am neyther a man nor a woman, I am an Hermaphrodite.
How? an Hermaphrodite? What would you doe among the Ladyes then.
An Hermaphrodite.
Let's search him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ah.
Stay let's be advis'd, if he be such a Monster, our best way is to carry him to the Duke.
Agreed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I shall be undone— d'yee heare Noble friends 'tis but a folly to dissemble, I am no such thing, I am no Hermaphrodite, I am a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of ours.
Your Name, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I did but jest all this while, the Duke himselfe put me upon't, to see whether I could cozen you, my Name's Morello.
Signior Morello, 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As I am vertuous, I am, I am no Hermaphrodite, no matter for the Gold or Diamonds tis your owne— Ile acquaint his Grace how carefull I found you, and if he doe not reward you beside, ile say hee's the poorest Duke in Christendome: Ile tell him presently.
Noble Signior wee'le waite vpon you to him.

sp.speaker: Mo,
sp.p: No, no, 'tis better for me to goe alone.
Your pardon, you shall tell him how carefull you found vs wee'le relate to him how cunningly you carried the businesse.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Nay d'yee heare Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It must be so Sir, come sweet effeminate Signior.

lg.l: Y'aue done me a noble office Signior in this
Discouery, where now liues her banished Louer?
My kinsman liues in Florence, but 2. dayes since
I receiued letters from him.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: In Florence too?

lg.l: Sir you may censure me,
But my affection to the iniurd Lord,
And not without respect vnto the Honor,
Of your Master too, hath bin the cause of
My free Language.
Trust me Signior
We are all ingag'd to study you a recompence,
But Mantua was iniust to banish him,
For being too much a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Sir, when Princes resolue to punish.

lg.l: Vertue shalbe Treason
'Twas tyranny,— why now is she thus cag'd?
I can coniecture nothing but his jealousie
Which wilbe euer actiue, by that Loue
Wee enterchang'd at Pisa, when wee grew
Together in our studies— I coniure
Your Noblenesse to silence me.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: You will dishonor me by suspition:— I am charmd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My honord Lord.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Signior Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: My gentile sparkes.

sp.speaker: Do. Gr.
sp.p: Your seruants.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: You are all Courtship.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Is your Lordship for this wonder?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: What wonder my Lord?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: These paire of Gentlemen haue discourst me into admiration, there's one has vndertaken to goe invisible.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Invisible?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This hower expected, and in this place.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: With a tricke that he has.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Doe you beleeve him, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: You shall see't.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wee were heretickes in that point, but our vnderstandings are convinc'd, he did demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And because you shall know the truth of his Art, he wilbe inuisible all but his hand, what thinke you of that? the rarest fellow in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Nothing visible but his hand.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: As sure as wee haue giuen him a 100. Crownes in hand.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Why is not the Duke presented with this noueltie.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hee's trauailing to the Emperour first, onely as he goes for our sake, he will shew vs a figgary of his Art.
Here's Rolliardo, hee's somewhat costiue a tother side wants Faith.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Saue you nest of Courtiers, smooth faces, rich clothes, and sublime complements, make you amorous in sight of your Ladies. Donzell del Phebo, and Rosiclees are you there? what pestilent diseases haue you got, that you weare so much musk and ciuet about you. Oh for a Priest of Cupid to sacrifice you now, how your breeches would burne like incense, & your haire disguised in sweet powder, leaue your bodies in a mist, while your bones were inwardly consuming with the fire of Dame Venus altar.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The same humorist still.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I heard say, wee shall haue strange apparitions i'th aire and yet invisible wonders, a hand must appeare as fatall to some as that hung o're the Capitoll; for there is a suspition some purses wilbe iugled emptie, and as silent as the Moone, no bright Sol appearing, nor a peece of pale fac'd siluer in your silken Hemispheres.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He is an Infidell.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Right Iehochanan, right, my precious Iew, wee are all In fidell that wonot beleeve the Court catechisme- my Lord Embassador you are welcome from Florence, does the great Duke pick sallats still, I meane continue his assize, returne into his Exchequer once in seauen yeares the wealth of Tuscany. Vespasian was held couetous for ordaining vessels to receiue the beneficiall publick vrine, but 'tis Heathenisme among Christians not to hold Dulcis odor Lucri è re qualibut.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: Hee's mad.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Signior Perenotto, it has puzzled my vnderstanding, how you can subsist at Court without making vse of the common sinnes, flattery, and corruption; take heed, y'are a great man, and 'tis ominous to dye in your bed, a signe your children are like to inherite but weake braines, thou maist goe to Heauen, but thy heire had rather thou shouldest make a journey to Erebus, for the proverbe sake, happy is that Sonne, whose Father goes to the Divell.— Why when comes out my Don invisible, may be, hee's heere already for wee cannot see him, what sayes my squirrill? thou lookst dull and Phisicall me thinkes, the crownes will returne agen invisibly, neuer feare it, and how does my graue Gymnosophist whose ambition is to be registred an honest Lord, though thou beest buried vpon almes, carried to Church with foure torches, and haue an inscription on thy marble worse then the ballad of the Devill and the Baker, and might be sung to as vilde a tune too.— Gentlemen, I'le invite you shortly to see my head cut off, and doe onely entreat, you would not laugh at me when I am dead, 'twill shew but poorely in you, and I shall reuenge it with my Ghost walking.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Either he is very confident to atchiue his designe or late growne desperate, he talkes so wildly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
I wonder, Signior Altomaro forgets vs. Now, now, yee shall heare, this is his seruant I know he is not
farre off, where is thy Master?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He is invisible— this Letter is directed to you.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: GEntlemen, that you may perceiue I deale plainely with you, I am now inuisible; all but my hand, and here it is, you may with ease read euery line, as I promised vpon the receipt of your Crownes.— his hand.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I Sir, 'tis his owne hand I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He does not meane to serue vs so, thou dost but iest, where is he invisible.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here I thinke, for I cannot see him, nor doe I know when I shall, or where he wilbe visible agen, vpon diligent search I found this paper, but my Master is not to be found.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Then he is invisible indeed.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: All but his hand. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I doe incline to beleeve, that wee are cheated.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: With a tricke that he has. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.p: You were Heretickes in that point, till he did demonstrate. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I cannot containe my merry spleene. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Come my Lord, lets leaue them now, to be their owne derision.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Signior Morello, ha, ha, ha. How came he in a Petticote.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Carry me away quickly, they wil laugh me out of my little wit.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: No, no, doe not Gentlemen, remember your selues.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Wee wonot then.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Morello? 'Ile waite vpon him to the Duke my selfe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What wise man in Italy would be in my coate now.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
I was costiue, and an Infidell, you are Christian coxcombes, and so, while I see what will become of the mirth, that is gone before, I leaue your wise Signiorships
to the mercy of your Garters, which is a speedy way, after a little time, to make your selves invisible indeed. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Signior Grutti we are gull'd.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I alwayes thought he would cheat us, what shall's doe, to prevent more laughter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I am resolv'd— I shall get no more money by him, Gentlemen be not head-hung, droope not, 'tis in this Sconce, to revenge your selves, and it may bee, recover your Crownes too.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Master—

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Is invisible, we know't too well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What will you give mee, if I discover him to your eyes agen, nay give him to your possession. Give him mony.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And this— oh quickly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Then first know, my Master is not that man you tooke him for, no Altomaro he, but Bonamico the decayd Artist, he that made Properties, and grew poore for want of Pictures, who for feare of his Creditors left his dwelling, and in this quaint disguise, set up the Trade of cozening such wise Gentlemen as you are.

sp.speaker: Grut. Dond.
sp.p: Bonamico!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Oh that we could reach him againe.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Follow me close, and I will bring you within an hayres bredth of his false Beard immediately.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: That will be excellent.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Nimbly good Mercury, nimbly.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Fidelia, Mardona, Donella, Catarina, Cassiava.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Madam you are too passive, if you bee deiected what must we, whose hopes and blisses depend upon your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Oh liberty, liberty; are all the Roman spirits extinct? Never a Brutus in Nature, to deliver poore Ladies from this Captivity.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p:
Since there is no probability of our enlargement, let's be merry, and despise our Sufferings, laugh, tell Tales,
sing, dance, any thing to cozen our melancholy.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: There are some thoughts that stick upon my memory, I would faine discharge.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Shall we try our Lutes Madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And voyces if you please.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes you may try, they say Musicke built the wals of Thebes, it were a greater myracle if you could charme these to fall, I shall never indure to live an Anchorite thus, and it were not for the happinesse that I doe sometimes dreame of a man, I should leape the Battlement. Now would I give all my jewels for the sight of a paire of Breeches, though there were nothing in em.
This but feedes our dulnesse, shall we dance Madam and stirre our selves.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: I am for that Musicke, we shall grow to the ground and we use no more activity.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: None a your dull measures, there's no sport but in your Country Figaries, a nimble dance will heate, and and make us merry.

div.stage: They dance, which done, a Bell rings.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Harke, the Bell.

stage.p: Exit Donella, and enters againe with a letter.

lg.l: Some newes from the Duke.
A Letter Madam and these iewels.
Ha! whence— from Florence? reades.
This is my fathers practise, ile peruse the Paper.
I have an excellent hint Ladyes of a mirth,
Cannot but please the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: What is't?

lg.l: It will require every ones indeavour,
What if we play some pretty Commick Story,

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: A Play?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Shall we?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wee? Doe not distrust your owne performance, I ha knowne men ha bin insufficient, but women can play their parts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I like it, t'wilbe new.

lg.l: Wee will not present it to the Princesse
But ingage her person in the action,
We shalbe too few else, some pretty Enterlude
To square with our number— d'yee allow it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come 'Ile acquaint you with a plot, then instantly: referre your selues to me for your parts, we can receiue no disparagement, our spectators cannot jeere vs, for weele speake but to the people in the hangings, and they haue as much Iudgment, as some men that are but Clothes, at most, but walking pictures.

sp.speaker: Fide.
sp.p: I shalbe ont.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: What part will you giue me, I'le be a King.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: thou't play a Tyrant brauely.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Let me alone, Ile fit you all I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Now our invisible Marchant is cag'd, wee may redeeme our opinion and passe agen in the ranke of discrete Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I thinke now to most of the beholders, he is invisible all but his head, for he has but a small grate to look out at.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He shall gull no more with his art I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Nay, he is like to lye by't, for I heare since, all his Creditors, like so many Crowes haue light vpon him, and they'le leaue him but a thin Carkasse.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Let 'em picke out his Eyes, what care wee.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He sent me an Epistle to take pitty on him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But I hope thou hast more wit then to shew thy selfe a Christian to such a Rascall as he is.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p:
I returned him my Court complement, that I was sorry I could not serue him: I would doe him any office that strecth'd not to mine owne prejudice, that
wee had taken order with his Keeper; vpon payment of our summes disburst, he might be enlarged.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Which is impossible.

Prethee let me see his Letter, in what submissiue language the Rogue does beseech vs,— Most heroique Signiors,— good— I throw my selfe at the feete of your mercy, for to your Iustice, I beg I may not be made a Sacrifice— nay, wee'll make him beg ere wee h'a done.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: At the grate.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I confesse I ha' done you wrong— does he so? it shall not serve the turne— there is no hope I shall euer satisfie you,— all the better, lye and rot— if I be known a Prisoner to my Creditors, I am irrecoverably lost, oh compassionate, a miserable man, who otherwise must soone forfeite his day light, and dye in a dungeon. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Saue you noble Signiors.—

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: — Ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: 'Tis Tis he.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Did he not dye in prison, and his Ghost haunts vs, braue!— 'Tis not hee.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: When this eternall substance of my Soule, did liue inprison'd in my wanton flesh, and so forth? and how d'yee like Don Andrea Gentlemen; poore snake, but hee has cast his skin, and recouered a new coate oth' destinyes spinning. The Bird is flowne againe.

sp.speaker: Don
sp.p: How the Diuell came he at liberty.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And thus Gallant.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: The slaue does not beg of your Heroicke Signiorship, a Court compassion, debts must be paid, there is no danger of the grate as the case goes, nor of forfeiting his daylight in a dungeon, if I mistake not, my illustrious paire of widgens, my serene smooth-fac'd Coxcombes, whose braines are curdled this hot weather: will your neate worship sell your cloake, ha? or you that superfluous double hatch'd Rapier, there be sommes in Nature to lend you, vpon security that I shall like of.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He jeeres vs.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Would wee durst beate him.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You see me now Gentlemen perfectly, what if I should walke before you without a body, my head hanging in the aire like a comet.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Would thou wer't hang'd any way.

lg.l: Heere's Rolliardo too.
Let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Or shall I appoint you a day when I will be invisible all but my hand?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, I thanke you Sir, we haue some businesse at this present.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Let's to the prison, and know the wonder better— Noble Signior.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: For your Crownes.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wee are glad wee had 'em for you, deare Signior talke no more on 'em,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Farewell Phantasmas then— ha? 'tis he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Keepe your way.

lg.l: You doe not know me
But I ha brought a life which by your meanes
Has bin preservd from wretchednesse, your Bounty,
Deserues you should dispose it.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What are you.

lg.l: I was the obiect of a charity
Wee seldome meete in Mankind, from a prison
You sent a summe to free me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Prethee friend, if th'ast receiu'd a benefit, goe home, and say thy prayers:— I would forget it.

lg.l: 'Mong many whom your Noblenesse inlarg'd,
I came to make you tender of my service:
Despise not Sir my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: D'yee mocke mee?

lg.l: May my soule want Heauens mercy then: to you,
Next my Creator, I doe owe my this Being
I haue a Soule is full of thankes, but name
Imployment to assure you, and you make me twice happy.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I ha nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Then I ha something to say to you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How.

lg.l: And you shall heare it too, and give me thankes
Y'ave sow'd your Charity in a fruitfull ground,
Which shall returne it tenfold; nay one hundred.
What you have done for me you shall acknowledge
I will deserve toth' height.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Th'art liberall in language.

lg.l: Ile be active— off with this sullen face,
It scurvily 'ecomes you, d'yee heare.
I studyed for you, since you payd my debts,
Ile doe you a courtesie and save your life,
Which your attempt upon the Princesse has
Left desperate, a happy fancy Sir,
If Heaven will please to prosper it, and you
Not be your owne enemy to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what mean'st?

lg.l: Nay you shall laugh and heartily ere I ha done w'e
The Duke does love his Daughter, sends her all
Rarities are presented to him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: His soule's not dearer to him— what of that?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Why then you shall be admitted into the Castle of comfort, that's all; the conceipt is in my braine, and would you could as probably get her consent, to untye her Virgin Zone, as I dispose your accesse to her: it shall not cost you much, if I fayle, instead of saying of my prayers, Ile curse the Destinies and dye with you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: D'yee heare, I ha bestow'd 300. Crownes already to set your heeles at Liberty, if you doe mocke mee, it shall cost me 500. but Ile ha' you clapt up agen, where you shall howle all day at the Grate, for a meale at Night from the Basket.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You are in earnest now?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: By all that you have threatned, so am I, have but the patience to walke and heare me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Can thy Art procure this?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: My Art? Why looke you, I made this Watch. Ile bestow it on you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What to doe? to reckon the houres I ha to live.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: It sha' not cost me so much trouble as that Toy did to make you master of your wishes, still if Heaven prosper it: come let's talke privately, you shall ha the plot.

lg.l: He that doth many good deeds it may fall,
Among the rest, one may reward them all.
I long to be discoursing it, pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Provide agen you mocke me not— come on Sir.

div.head: Scaena, I.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: ROllyardo pay his debts? Sure the fellow that never saw much money in's life, now by the Duke made Master of so many summes, is growne madde with 'em.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Many other he hath discharg'd they say.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: He'l undoe the Exchequer, and hee hold on, he shall be Chronicl'd for't.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He has some cause to imagine himselfe short liv'd, and that makes him so desperately charitable, toward his end. Signior Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: Dondolo and Grutti, Newes, Newes for yee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What we beseech you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You have lost the best mirth in Italy in your absence, your Companion Morello—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Was carryed to the Duke in a Peticote, in which he attempted a passage to the sequestred Ladyes— what's the yssue.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Mirth in Aboundance.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How came he off?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Nay 'tis on still, the Duke to make himselfe sport, would call a Counsell, before whom the poore Signior
must be arraign'd; not to hold you in circumstance, the Businesse was merrily discust, & the pitifull proiector was iudg'd—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To weare the petticote for a Month, if he appeare without it during the Terme, hee incurres his perpetuall exile from Court.

sp.speaker: Don. Gru.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You may imagine with what variety of lamentable faces, the Courtier heard his unexpected sentence, some would have pleaded for him but for laughter, which continued so long and so high, that he had time to collect his scattered senses, and instead of sowning, which was expected, he grew fortifi'd, and most humbly besought the Duke, since his sentence had past so definitive, hee would be so mercifull, to admit him that course of a Moone to be his Ieaster, that since hee could not shake off the Fooles Coat, that he might have that favourable pretence to keepe it on.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Very good—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Twas easily granted, but ever since, to the astonishment of the hearers, he is growne so iocund and ayrie, nay as if he had beene borne with a Song in's head, he talkes everlasting Ballad, no man laughes at him but hee lashes him in Rime worse then a Satyr, the Duke has priviledg'd his mirth, made him foole-free, and now hee playes the Tyrant— hee's here already.

lg.l: Oyes, o yes, o yes,
If there be any one in City or in Towne
Can shew me a wise man Ile please him for his paine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Disgrace has made him witty.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What will you say to him, will shew you a wise man?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Marry if he goe farre, he is not so wise as hee should be. Dondolo, Grutti! Old acquaintance how is't? How is't?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The case is alter'd with you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It does appeare so, but nothing can make mee proud, Ile know my Fellowes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How doe you meane Morello?

lg.l: Your Lordship may make one at Football,
Tis all the sport now a dayes.
What other is the world then a Ball,
Which we run after with whoope and with hollow,
He that doth catch it is sure of a fall,
His heeles tript up by him that doth follow.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Doe not women play too?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: They are too light, quickly downe.

sp.speaker: Mor.

lg.l: Oyes, they are the best Gamesters of all,
For though they often lye on the ground,
Not one amongst a hundred will fall,
But under her coates the Ball will found.

sp.p: But we be three of old, without exception to your Lordship, onely with this difference, I am the wisest Foole, for you play the foole in your old clothes, and I have a new Coate on.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Does it not become him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Rarely well, doe you ever meane to resigne it.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: 'Twere pitty but he should have a patent for't, to him and his posterity.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Harke you Gentlemen, d'yee heare the Newes?

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Newes! what newes?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Dee not heare on't yet, why 'tis in a Ballad already.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And thou canst sing it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
